awd_abstract_narration:
This S-STEM scholarship project for low income students focuses on preparing engineers with the skills required to be part of a global engineering workforce. The Global Engineering Preparedness Scholarship (GEPS) program includes strategies to equip a total of 25 academically talented, low income students to enroll and graduate from the Swanson School of Engineering at University of Pittsburgh with technical, global competency and leadership skills.  With the development  of students' intercultural and global competency skills, the GEPS program is addressing the National Academy of Engineering's Educating the Engineer of 2020 (2005) call for preparing engineers to be leaders in global engineering fields.

The goals of the GEPS program are to: 1) provide access, through scholarship opportunities, to engineering education to talented low income students to enroll and graduate in engineering, with concerted effort to increase the enrollment of underrepresented minority (URM) students; 2) provide continuous academic support for the retention and graduation of GEPS scholars in engineering; and 3) provide opportunities for GEPS scholars to develop global competency and leadership experience.  Scholars gain global leadership experiences by selecting from four options: stay-at-home service learning activities, internships, Engineering for Humanity Certificate capstone design course, or study abroad experiences with on-location projects.  Recruitment strategies include emphasis on transfer students, who typically are not provided scholarship opportunities. Evaluators will provide formative feedback to assist in iteratively improving  global engineering preparedness, peer and faculty mentoring, academic counseling, tutoring, and other program components.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The University of Pittsburgh Swanson School of Engineering (PITT)  Global Engineering Preparedness Scholarship (GEPS) program was funded by NSF S-STEM award  in 2015. GEPS? primary objectives were focused on students? Access (enrollment through increased scholarships for low-income US citizens and permanent resident students with unmet financial needs), Retention through continuous academic  mentorship, and  Global Competency and Leadership Experience (GLE). GEPS scholars were selected from the pool of students with initial interest in PITT engineering, admitted students, or transferring students meeting citizenship requirements through the Office of Admissions and Financial Aid. Selection criteria included high school top 10-20%  class ranking and unmet financial need. The key outcomes of GEPS  included: increase in enrollment of low-income students with unmet financial needs,  increase in  under-represented minorities (URMs) that benefited from study abroad,  internships and  faculty-led research opportunities, transition to graduate school, and gain in Global Leadership Experience (GLE).

The outcomes of GEPS GLE courses are documented in the attached reports from the internal and external evaluation teams. Only excerpts from those reports are included  here.

Intellectual Merit: GEPS advanced our  understanding of global engineering solution  within engineering and  across different fields, and countries, Specifically:

  • GEPS GLE  program was a  transformative, intellectual concept, and the most significant and sustainable outcomes of from GEPS program. The GLE activities included a combination of yearly  academic supports and a two-week study abroad course. The course, entitled Empathic Leadership for Social Change: South Africa (formerly named Engineering Design for Social Change: South Africa (SA). The  course exposed students to cultural contexts in designing solutions to societal problems including racial inequality, economic disparities, mass immigration, climate change, etc. South Africa experiences in these problems provided  excellent context  for the course.  
  • GEPS program was associated with a positive, significant perceived impact on global engineering workforce preparedness, which was a key objective of the program, and  students? self-confidence in their ability to perform well at an engineering job; perceived ability in  professional and technical skill areas significantly increased between the start of the GEPS program and the end of the program. 
  • Seventy-five percent  of the students surveyed indicated an awareness or understanding of global, social, societal, or cultural issues with respect to engineering as well as exposure to alternative perspectives. 
  • About forty-four percent of responses indicated that GEPS was  impactful over all, with  significant perception of change in global engineering workforce preparedness.  A student noted:

?The study abroad trip was absolutely amazing for this.  We were able to learn about a different culture and their own problems and challenges and solve engineering problems in this context.  This is something you can only talk about from home. I would never have had this opportunity without the GEPS program.  I can't think of a better way to become a global engineer than to actually practice in another country for a time.? 

  • Differences in preparedness for global engineering workforce and self-confidence in engineering professional performance,  during the students? time in the GEPS program were found to be statistically (α = 0.05) and  practically significant.    
  • The difference in GEPS participants? self-confidence in their engineering professional performance was also significant during their time in the GEPS program, increasing  from an average rating of 3.53 to 4.05,  with  (p = 0.038).  

 

Broader Impact: GEPS  global problem design concept  can lead to  desired societal impacts:

  •  36 students enrolled in the GEPS program over the five years: 27  graduated in engineering, 8 left the program (some dismissed for not meeting program requirement or  remained at PITT), and 1 left PITT entirely, representing overall program retention of over 80%;  URM students enrollment increased from 3.6% in 2014 prior to GEPS to 11% in 2020 and 9.6% in 2021; 32 of the 36 scholars (89%) participated in co-op,  27 (75%) in faculty-led research or internship, and more than 9 of the 27  graduates (over 33%) transitioned to MS/PhD degree programs. The number of URMs that participated  in study  abroad increased from 8% in 2014 to 14% in 2021.
  • GLE courses that  began in summer of 2016  is now offered to all undergraduates across the university. As of summer, 2022, a total number of 87 PITT students and 45 SA students (South African College of Applied Psychology (SACAP), Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), and University of Johannesburg (UJ)) have participated and been impacted by the GEPS courses. These students shared  cultural perspectives that contributed greatly to the growth outcomes of the entire group.
  • The  courses resulting from the GEPS program, now extend opportunity for global experience to other students in and outside engineering disciplines and in SA.
  • Students (37.5%) mostly attributed the strength of GEPS program to 1) community support, 2) mentoring  by faculty, and 3) a sense of motivation, accountability, and program focus areas; 25% indicated that the program strength was in developing their global communications skills within engineering work.   

  

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Sylvanus Wosu

por.por_txt_cntn:
The University of Pittsburgh Swanson School of Engineering (PITT)  Global Engineering Preparedness Scholarship (GEPS) program was funded by NSF S-STEM award  in 2015. GEPS? primary objectives were focused on students? Access (enrollment through increased scholarships for low-income US citizens and permanent resident students with unmet financial needs), Retention through continuous academic  mentorship, and  Global Competency and Leadership Experience (GLE). GEPS scholars were selected from the pool of students with initial interest in PITT engineering, admitted students, or transferring students meeting citizenship requirements through the Office of Admissions and Financial Aid. Selection criteria included high school top 10-20%  class ranking and unmet financial need. The key outcomes of GEPS  included: increase in enrollment of low-income students with unmet financial needs,  increase in  under-represented minorities (URMs) that benefited from study abroad,  internships and  faculty-led research opportunities, transition to graduate school, and gain in Global Leadership Experience (GLE).

The outcomes of GEPS GLE courses are documented in the attached reports from the internal and external evaluation teams. Only excerpts from those reports are included  here.

Intellectual Merit: GEPS advanced our  understanding of global engineering solution  within engineering and  across different fields, and countries, Specifically:

GEPS GLE  program was a  transformative, intellectual concept, and the most significant and sustainable outcomes of from GEPS program. The GLE activities included a combination of yearly  academic supports and a two-week study abroad course. The course, entitled Empathic Leadership for Social Change: South Africa (formerly named Engineering Design for Social Change: South Africa (SA). The  course exposed students to cultural contexts in designing solutions to societal problems including racial inequality, economic disparities, mass immigration, climate change, etc. South Africa experiences in these problems provided  excellent context  for the course.   
GEPS program was associated with a positive, significant perceived impact on global engineering workforce preparedness, which was a key objective of the program, and  students? self-confidence in their ability to perform well at an engineering job; perceived ability in  professional and technical skill areas significantly increased between the start of the GEPS program and the end of the program.  
Seventy-five percent  of the students surveyed indicated an awareness or understanding of global, social, societal, or cultural issues with respect to engineering as well as exposure to alternative perspectives.  
About forty-four percent of responses indicated that GEPS was  impactful over all, with  significant perception of change in global engineering workforce preparedness.  A student noted:


?The study abroad trip was absolutely amazing for this.  We were able to learn about a different culture and their own problems and challenges and solve engineering problems in this context.  This is something you can only talk about from home. I would never have had this opportunity without the GEPS program.  I can't think of a better way to become a global engineer than to actually practice in another country for a time.?  

Differences in preparedness for global engineering workforce and self-confidence in engineering professional performance,  during the students? time in the GEPS program were found to be statistically (α = 0.05) and  practically significant.    
The difference in GEPS participants? self-confidence in their engineering professional performance was also significant during their time in the GEPS program, increasing  from an average rating of 3.53 to 4.05,  with  (p = 0.038).  


 

Broader Impact: GEPS  global problem design concept  can lead to  desired societal impacts:

 36 students enrolled in the GEPS program over the five years: 27  graduated in engineering, 8 left the program (some dismissed for not meeting program requirement or  remained at PITT), and 1 left PITT entirely, representing overall program retention of over 80%;  URM students enrollment increased from 3.6% in 2014 prior to GEPS to 11% in 2020 and 9.6% in 2021; 32 of the 36 scholars (89%) participated in co-op,  27 (75%) in faculty-led research or internship, and more than 9 of the 27  graduates (over 33%) transitioned to MS/PhD degree programs. The number of URMs that participated  in study  abroad increased from 8% in 2014 to 14% in 2021. 
GLE courses that  began in summer of 2016  is now offered to all undergraduates across the university. As of summer, 2022, a total number of 87 PITT students and 45 SA students (South African College of Applied Psychology (SACAP), Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), and University of Johannesburg (UJ)) have participated and been impacted by the GEPS courses. These students shared  cultural perspectives that contributed greatly to the growth outcomes of the entire group. 
The  courses resulting from the GEPS program, now extend opportunity for global experience to other students in and outside engineering disciplines and in SA. 
Students (37.5%) mostly attributed the strength of GEPS program to 1) community support, 2) mentoring  by faculty, and 3) a sense of motivation, accountability, and program focus areas; 25% indicated that the program strength was in developing their global communications skills within engineering work.
